results.title: Wave particle duality
results.brief_description: Introduces and discusses the dual nature of light and matter and traces the development of the theory of wave-particle duality. A demonstration showing beams of electrons and neutrons creating a picture of wave motion similar to light’s wave motion is also given.
results.description: Introduces and discusses the dual nature of light and matter and traces the development of the theory of wave-particle duality. A demonstration showing beams of electrons and neutrons creating a picture of wave motion similar to light’s wave motion is also given.

results.title: Wave from Atlantic
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American visions”.
At the turn of the twentieth century, huge waves of immigration confirmed America’s multicultural character forever. The immigrants’ struggle was also fundamental in creating a new truly popular culture; the movies. A new social conscience began to emerge as the photography of Jacob Riis and the social realism of the Ashcan School replaced effete salon art and American impressionism. Its subjects were often gleaned from the slums and sweat shops of New York City’s Lower East Side. American modernism began with the paintings of Marsden Hartley, and it is also found in the slangy collages of Arthur Dove, who anticipated Pop Art. Futurism found its American counterpart in the Perfectionist paintings of Charles Sheeler, who immortalized the Machine Age in his paintings of Ford’s industrial Mecca at River Rouge. Finally, nature provided inspiration for modernism, too, in the revolutionary buildings of America’s greatest twentieth-century architect, Frank Lloyd Wright. If westward expansion had been the predominant story of the nineteenth century, it was now a question of building upwards, with skyscrapers symbolizing the mood of unparalleled self-confidence for America in the twenties. But as many of the skyscrapers were on the verge of completion, America was rocked by events on Wall Street. The crash of 1929 was to change America forever. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Wave and quantum theories
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Light”.
Demonstrates the accepted theory of light as consisting of both wave motion and of discrete bundles or quanta of energy. Performs Young’s double-slit experiment to show the wave character of light. Shows in laboratory demonstrations and in animation the Compton effect and other major experiments associated with the present theory.

results.title: Wave-partical duality
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Traces the development of the various theories advanced to explain the behaviour of light, from the concepts of the ancient Greeks to current proven models. The contributions of Isaac Newtown, Christian Huygens, Thomas Young, Jean Foucault, Albert Einstein and others are outlined as are the reasons for the gradual acceptance of both particle and wave models and their eventual combination. The six 10 minute episodes are: 1. “The Particle model” 2. “The Wave model” 3. “The Electromagnetic model” 4. “The Quantum idea” 5. “Photons” 6. “Matter waves.”

results.title: Wattle ballad. No. 1. My old black billy
results.brief_description: The song of the swagman who intends to “stick to me sensible, indispensable, old black billy”, sung by male voices and illustrated by shots of the swagman’s life. Arranged and sung by The Ramblers. Cast features Jock Levy.

results.title: Watt's last voyage
results.creator_credit: Brian Davies and University of Melbourne. Film Society
results.brief_description: A tale told with humour and pathos; a yarn spun between decks about an old salt whose bitter experiences one friendless dawn persuade him to abandon wayfaring for wading. Cast includes Graeme Blundell, Robin Laurie, John Wregg.

results.title: Waterworld
results.brief_description: A ridiculed adaptation of the Kevin Costner vehicle Waterworld, which translated the Mad Max narrative from the desert to the sea.

constellations_other.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_other.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

results.description: The sun. For millions of years the source of life. But for one planet the source of it’s demise. The temperature climbed, the vast pools of ice at it’s poles melted, and the oceans rose. Centuries later, few people remained on this planet, once called Earth. A lone mariner sails the expanse of water, trading to survive. For survival, is all these people do, in this place they know only as Waterworld.

results.title: Waterworks
results.brief_description: ‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology.
